WORLDS IN COLLISION (Doubleday ir Company., Inc., Garden City., New Yodfc) This earlier book by Immanuel Velikovsky created a furor all over the world when it was published in April of 1950, a furor that has not yet subsided. A campaign was carried on to create the im- pression that the press of this country had rejected the book. Here are a few comments from favorable reviews about this work, the most controversial volume in many decades: N. Y. HERALD TRIBUNE, John J. O'Neill: Dr. Immanuel Velikovsky has assembled into a monumental work evidence from all the early civilizations that in the first and second millennium B. G. tremendous terrestrial cataclysms took place. In a magnificent piece of scholarly his- torical research, there unfolds a most exciting picture of terrestrial events that raises world history to a level of superlative interest. Obscure allu- sions to events in classical and sacred literature become crystal clear as he fits together the jigsaw puzzle of his- tory* Dr. Vclikovsky's work presents a stupendous panorama of terrestrial and human histories which will stand as a challenge to scientists to frame a realistic picture of the cosmos. HARPER'S MAGAZINE, Eric Lar- rabee: Philosophy, science, religion there is scarcely an area of knowl- edge or conviction invulnerable to Dr. Vclikovsky's detailed and docu- mented denial that the Earth's his- tory hft been one of peaceful evolution . * . Bringing to this per- spective all the apparatus of learn- ing, Dr. Velikovsky has undertaken the awesome task of making an "in- quiry into the architectonics of the world and its history" and of apply- ing the techniques of scholarship and psychoanalysis to the entire hu- man race. READER.'S DIGEST, Fulton Ours- ler: A single scholar has sought a synthesis of knowledge and reason in the field of science, legend and religion. The result is a theory of earth's history as a planet, fascinat- ing as a tale by Jules Verne, yet documented with a scholarship worthy of Darwin. COLLIER'S, Editor: "Worlds in Collision" promises to be one of the most controversial books of the year, perhaps of the decade . Tre- mendous volume of research amassed by the author over a period of ten years. Although the theories Dr. Velikovsky expresses are certain to provoke debate, prominent scientific

and religious leaders have found them most extraordinary. NEWSWEEK: Velikovsky, a broad- gauge savant with an incredible field of competence in the sciences . . . confirms the Bible . . . His final con- clusions are even world-shaking . . * If Velikovsky's monumental work stands, it will upset prevailing views in evolution, physical science and history. NEWSWEEK, "Professors as Sup- pressors": Although some of the critics who reviewed Velikovsky's book considered it a major scientific contribution, there could be little question but that it had driven the vast majority of the nation's scien- tists into a highly unacademic fury. For Velikovsky challenges all the present concepts and laws of history, astronomy, biology, and geology. One of the most cherished rights of the nation's teaching profession is academic freedom. . . . Yet a small group of professors themselves stood accused of a major assault on aca- demic freedom. PAGEANT: Nothing in recent years has so excited the public imagina- tion, or stirred up so heated a con- troversy, as the fascinating new theory advanced by Dr. Immanucl Velikovsky, physician, scientist, his- torian, philosopher. Its inferences past and future, are so great and far reaching as to make the hydro- gen bomb and 1950 troubles seem like child's play. ASSOCIATED PRESS, Robert W. Blakeslee, Science Editor: The book upsets all cosmological assumptions that the solar system planets have revolved in their present orbits for billions of years. UNITED PRESS, Paul F. Ellis, Science Editor: "Worlds in Colli- sion" caused a commotion among astronomers but Velikovsky said: "Let them disprove the historical records on which my book is based." NEW REPUBLIC, Harold L. Ickes: Dr. Velikovsky has conferred a great boon upon all of us. He has given us something to think about; some- thing even to pray about . . . Per- haps we shall have sense enough to put our heads between our hands and do some real thinking about universal and lasting peace. BOOK-OF-THE-MONTH CLUB NEWS, John J. O'Neill: Tf you want an intellectual jolt read "Worlds in Collision" by Dr. Immanuel Veli- kovsky. It will furnish your mind with a new set of horizons. For here is a volume filled with events, stu- pendous, cataclysmic terrestrial and cosmic . . . This is not just a wonder book. It is a serious presentation by a sincere scholar, and there is a deep philosophic significance underlying" it. Dr. Velikovsky provides an array' of evidence to support his claims. Scholars may disagree with Dr. Velikovsky 's conclusions. To minds blinded by too much orthodoxy they may seem fantastic. They are, never- theless, worthy of most serious; thought. Science and history have been standing pat for entirely too long on a theory of man and naiure that excludes the possibility of events outside a dull, safe routine. They have achieved this static program by hanging velvet curtains of taboo around embarrassing situations. They are ripe for a jolt* Dr. Velikovsky has pulled some of the curtains aside. EVERYBODY'S DIGEST, Editor: This remarkable ten-year study may rock the civilized worfd challenging

both our religious concepts and the theory of evolution. THIS WEEK MAGAZINE, Gordon A. Atwater: Even before the book's publication it has been the subject of a storm of controversy that has swept across the nation ... I do contend that, looking at it from an over-all point of view, the author has done a tremendous job, the effect of which is to link science and religion. His book will have an explosive effect in the world of science. The greatest value of "Worlds in Collision" is this: It sots up an unusual approach to some of the world's great prob- lems. An astounding feat of research ... an amazing list of sources. In assembling those proofs Dr. Vclikov- sky has plunged headlong into a dozen difToront sciences and has dug deeply itito the roots of many. Dr. Velikovsky, realizing the impact of his thesis, has gone to very great lengths to reveal his method so that it may be searched in detail * . . Although the opening impact of this theory due to its sensational nature is certain to arouse violent hos- tility, even this feeling will be set aside as it is searched and probed for errors and truths. SATURDAY EVENING POST, Editorial: One of the most astonish- ing episodes was the effort of Ameri- can scientists to suppress a book, Worlds in Collision. . . . Doctor Vclikovsky's offense seems to be that he writes bettor than most scientists and m his book expounds a theory of astronomical activity which dif- fers widely from orthodox theories. ... So the orthodox scientists, for- getting about Galileo, and the long, woeful struggle of scientists to be free of dogma, acted like the author- itarians with whom they are con- tinually in conflict, . . Not even a silly season ought to excuse scien- tists for book burning. After all, they are always the chief victims of this kind of intolerance. PATHFINDER: Top-flight scientists think "Worlds in Collision" will force reconsideration of the basic postulates of many major sciences. AMERICAN MERCURY: The cen- tral thesis of this book is stupendous. Dr. Velikovsky, who seems to be a veritable cyclopedia of learning, draws upon all the sciences and arts to buttress his thesis. N. Y. SUNDAY MIRROR MAGA- ZINE, H. William Smith: "Worlds in Collision" presents arguments to prove that famous colossal miracles of ancient times, as related in folk- lore and religious literature, actually happened. As Velikovsky sees it, our apparently well-ordered universe is like a fireworks factory which an erratic spark may explode any min- ute. The promulgation of this thesis is expected to excite heated objec- tions in the scientific world, but Velikovsky makes a very plausible case* N. Y. SUNDAY NEWS, Editorial: "Worlds in Collision" is raising such a terrific furor in scientific cir- cles that we don't see how a news- paper which claims to be on its toes can ignore the book or dodge from frank discussion of it. Dr. Vclikov- sky, a widely-travelled scholar and scientific investigator, oilers a flock of theories which make orthodox scientists foam at the mouth. [He] challenges them to prove him mis- taken. If we might presume to offer the scientific brotherhood a tip, it would be to get busy trying to dis- prove Velikovsky with facts and fig-

ures, and lay off trying to promote boycotts aimed at his book. N. Y. JOURNAL & AMERICAN, George E. Sokolsky: Certain scien- tists threatened with a boycott. Of course, what the learned and liberal professors wanted was the total sup- pression of a book which opposes their dogma. Scientists tend to be- come dogmatic like theologians, whom they denounce as dogmatic. N. Y. SUNDAY COMPASS, Ted. O. Thackrey: There is excellent ground for suggesting that Dr. Velikovsky's findings thus far may well rank him in contemporary and future history with Galileo, Newton, Planck, Kep- ler, Darwin, Einstein, and the other great intellects who have in turn bade us revise our theories of what the world is like and what laws gov- ern it and its relation to the uni- verse. BOSTON GLOBE, Marion L. Star- key: Probably the most stimulating horror story that has ever been writ- ten. There is something of poetry, of divine justice about the theory. BOSTON POST, A.GJL Dietz (Pro- fessor at Massachusetts Institute of Technology): Velikovsky proposed a bold and startling thesis . . . and results in a book that is absorbing reading ... It seems certain that there must at one time have been a sudden shifting of the Earth's axis. BOSTON POST, Lester Allen: Only a generation of time and re-exami- nation of the evidence presented by Velikovsky will show whether he is merely a brilliant improviser or a profound discoverer of a new prin- ciple. The challenge that Velikovsky presents to modern science may ac- complish something more for the troubled and frightened people of the world than putting their scien- tific house in order, however. It may give a death blow to the growing skepticism of many people whose faith in the Divine Creator had been shaken in the name of scientific en- lightenment by the debunkers of the holy books. N. Y. TIMES BOOK REVIEW, David Dempsey: Among general non-fiction, "Worlds in Collision" was being outsold by only one book the Bible. The epicenter of a liter- ary earthquake. PHILADELPHIA INQUIRER: John M. McCullough: Few books have so stirred the world of thought- ful men; the arguments pro and con inevitably must reverberate through learned societies for months to come. It is this its role as a potent fer- ment in a world of not too settled thought which imbues "Worlds in Collision" with its real significance. PITTSBURGH PRESS, Florence Fisher Perry: It is moro fascinating reading than anything to be found on any fiction table. It is absolutely original and convincing. CHICAGO HERALD-AMERICAN: A fabulous story , . . This book is revolutionary and may prove almost as world-shaking as if Venus had changed her settings again. It is writ- ten so that any one can understand. CHICAGO SUN-TIMES, Emmett Dedmon: "Worlds in Collision" is clearly written and well-enough but- tressed with data to startle any reader into a re-examination of his ideas about the world. And I expect it may provoke one of the biggest arguments since Einstein said the

shortest distance between two points was a curved line. THE CRESSET, Chicago, 111., Er- \vin J. Buls: Seldom has one theory extended into so many fields of hu- man thought and drawn on so many for its evidence . . . "Worlds in Collision" presents such an array of evidence that it cannot be ignored, while the high degree of scholarship evident throughout the book does not permit derisive dismissal. Writ- ten in non-technical language, lay- man and scientist will find it fas- cinating. BALTIMORE EVENING SUN: Velikovsky has built a powerful case for the contention that those ac- counts reflect occurrences which did actually take place . . And science does not yet have any way of its own to explain these "Miracles." CLEVELAND PRESS, Tom Board- man: It's a book that will be dis- cussed, studied, challenged and de- fended for many years. DALLAS TIMES-HERALD, Ken- neth Koran: Startling, astounding, amazing and entirely revolutionary story of the universe. SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS, Henry H, Lawrence: A book of absorbing interest and one bound to excite dis- cussion and further elucidation for years to come. PORTLAND JOURNAL, Larry Howes: It can be understood and argued about by laymen, and It blacks the eye of Dogmatic Science* PORTLAND OREGONIAN: A high percentage of those whose fields are invaded and their facts questioned may be expected to rise to the chal- lenge. The minds that will be stimu- lated by this book are the world's best. Who knows what may come of that? PORTLAND (Me.) TELEGRAM, K. W. Berry: If the theory set forth by Velikovsky stands the acid test to which it undoubtedly will be sub- jected, it will upset the foundation of the world's natural sciences and contravene theological claims for many miracles described in the Old Testament . * . His countless cita- tions build up a strong case a case which scarcely seems to depend on coincidence. DAYTON NEWS, Herbert Shaw: Surely Immanucl Velikovsky has written so controversial a book that it will be the subject of much de- bate and much diligent intellectual searching in the years to come. He is to be admired and congratulated for the documentation he has presented. DENVER POST, Edward V. Dund- Ice: "Worlds in Collision" is easily the most discussed book of the year, deals with the truth or falsity of these ancient biblical stories. Read this book with an open mind and a new vista of ideas will be opened. MIAMI HERALD, Beatrice Wash- bum: This book has literally shaken the thinking world to its foundations, Not since Darwin's "Origin of the Species" has there been advanced an idea so original, controversial, and stupendous in its implications. MONTGOMERY, Alabama, AD- VERTISER, W. J, Mahoney, Jr.: You are likely to hear it debated furiously . . . Whether you're an expert on the subject or merely some one who merely looks into the sky occasionally at night to wonder at its

magnificent and mysterious beauty, you'll find this book exciting and imagination-stirring ... It is a book that will supply many an evening of spirited conversation for the draw- ing rooms of the world. LOUISVILLE, Kentucky, COUR- IER-JOURNAL, Joseph Landau: Velikovsky has hurled his interpre- tation of biblical events and world history into a world that is in chaos. It could be a book that will affect the thinking of the ages. "Worlds in Collision" could easily become one of the most important books of the soth century. RALEIGH NEWS OBSERVER, Allen Alexander: Once in a great while you may be fortunate enough to come across a truly amazing book. This is far more than that it may well become a bible. His descrip- tions will make your spine tingle as it never has before. Actually, this book is as easy to read as a western and much more exciting. TENNESSEEAN, Nashville, Tenn., Charles L. Fontenay: The term "revolutionary" is all too frequently applied to books in these days when a couple of months seems to be the maximum accepted period between new theories of various kinds. The term, however, could fit Dr. Veil- kovsky*s book, BERKELEY GAZETTE, California: The book has aroused speculation and controversies throughout the country ... If Dr. Velikovsky is right, there will be many red faces among the reviewers of the land. OAKLAND POST ENQUIRER: It is difficult to laugh away the paral- lels of legend and tradition . . . you encounter some vast panoramas that are most stimulating to thought PROVIDENCE JOURNAL, Ken- neth B. Roberts: An incredibly sim- ple solution of scores of baffling problems of antiquity . . . But right or wrong, rational or ridiculous, this is fascinating fare. ROCKY MOUNTAIN NEWS, Den- ver, CoL, Lee Casey: One of the most amazing and persuasive books I have ever read: "Worlds in Colli- sion," by Velikovsky. He sweeps away the cxegetcs. The stories we learned in Sunday School, he tells us, were not mere legends but straight facts. To be sure, he did not con- vince his fellow-scholars. Neither, for that matter, did Pythagoras, Thales, Galileo or Copernicus. Now, as in the time of these worthies, scholars merely smiled and said, "The case had not been proved," But I do submit he convinced me. ROCKY MOUNTAIN NEWS, A. Branscombe: This is, without any doubt, the most sensational book of the soth century. If the facts in it stand up under cold analysis by other scientists, and this reviewer be- lieves 90 per cent of them will, al- most every other scientific and his- torical textbook in the world is out- dated . . . No book since Darwin promises to have such an impact on every phase of science^ history, philosophy and religion . . * Dr, Velikovsky's claims . * . are told in language simple enough for virtu- ally any reader, and will prove fas- cinating for layman and scientist alike ... In short, this is extraordi- nary. Don't miss it. LOS ANGELES TIMES, Maximil- ian Berners: Controversy wilt be- come more and more violent as the book gctn known, There is plenty of excitement, following Velikov- sky's trail of fire, smoke, brim* stone, hurricane and earthquake.

FREDERICK, Oklahoma, LEADER: A volume of endless fascination. CONGRESS WEEKLY, Jacob S. Minkin: Many threads the author has woven into the tremendous tap- estry that is "Worlds in Collision." The story goes on, interesting, in- structive and exciting to the end. In many ways the book is breathtaking, moving along like a celestial drama with comets and planets for its dramatis pcisonae. THE NATIONAL JEWISH POST, Ward Moore: Scientists are no more receptive to new ideas than any other group subscribing to crystal- lized dogma. It is therefore not at all surprising that Immanuel Veli- kovsky has been denounced as a heretic. "Worlds in Collision" ques- tioned the infallibility of some ap- parently natural laws. A tremendous amount of t orritory is taken in; nevertheless, documentation is of- fered for each particular. Unless reader's prejudices arc completely blind it is difficult to see how he can dismiss "Worlds in Collision.'* OKLAHOMA CITY OKLAHO- MAN, Alice Hughes: Dinner tables in our war-jittery town are agog with this eerie volume* DETROIT NEWS, Clyde Beck: A strange and wonderful book. EVENING DISPATCH, Edinburgh, Scotland: No lx>ok in rece.nt times has boon the subject of so much controversy. Soim*. scientists let loose a flood of tlenuwiaiory criticism and hysterical protests against the publi- cation. . . . What we liave iu this piece of cholarly research h the history of the earth as a planet, fas- cinatingly told and truthfully docu- mented OXFORD MAIL, Oxford, England: Fascinating alike in its stupendous pictures of a world in the grip of cosmic forces, in its parallels drawn from the annals of the ancients in many lands, and its vast implica- tions. THE TIMES, London: Dr. Veli- kovsky is a man of much learning and he has mastered the commen- taries upon the text and all books on cosmology as well. . . . [The book's] reputation has been . . . en- hanced by dark stories of scientists allegedly applying pressure by boy- cotting the text book department of the author's first publishing house in a frenzied effort to prevent the de- struction of their own reputation and of orthodox physics. GLASGOW DAILY RECORD, Glasgow, Scotland: Gigantic, sensa- tional, staggering. METHODIST RECORDER, Lon- don, England: A thriller that is surely without a peer. JEWISH CHRONICLE, London, Dr. Silverstone: For one scholar to have written this book, necessitating as it docs an encyclopedic knowl- edge of science, history, and folk- lore, is a remarkable achievement. EDINBURGH EVENING NEWS: The strength of his evidence is great* It is a truly wonderful book. ABERDEEN PRESS, Aberdeen, Scotland: Probably no book in our generation has caused so much con- troversy. . * , In the scientific world it caused a veritable explo- sion of bad temper.

COMMERCIAL APPEAL, Mem- phis: "Worlds in Collision" has opened new debate in science. Ef- forts have been made to dismiss this work by calling it "rubbish" and "nonsense" but this will not answer the evidence he has compiled. It is a foregone conclusion that the book will call for renewed investigation from others of the facts so long ac- cepted. If it does no more, the au- thor has rendered a noble service to his profession and to his fellow men. TORONTO SATURDAY NIGHT, Editorial: The American scientific world has gone through a cataclysm almost as violent as those referred to by Dr. Velikovsky. CHRISTIAN CENTURY, W. E. Garrison: The book is exciting read- ing. The two Wellses (H.G. and Orson) might have collaborated to conceive it. CHRISTIAN SCIENCE MONI- TOR, Boston: This verification of the Bible seems to us of real impor- tance. It shows what are sometimes called "miracles" to be not viola- tions of law but higher demonstra- tions of spiritual law than the ma- terialist deems possible. CHRISTIAN HERALD: The vol- ume is both daring and original and perhaps reckless. But also it is fascinating. THE LIVING CHURCH, Milwau- kee, Editorial: If you are worried about Russia or the hydrogen bomb, read "Worlds in Collision." The cataclysms therein described make even the horrors foreshadowed in the daily papers fade. This work is heavily documented and ranges over an amazing variety of fields of learn- ing. PRESBYTERIAN, Philadelphia: The greatest storm center in the literary and scientific worlds. CHRISTIAN REGISTER, Boston: Dr. Velikovsky has done us a very great service: he has jarred the complacency of our thinking; he has emphasized the importance of un- derstanding and grasping the sig- nificance of early tradition, and has stressed again the limitations of human knowledge. AUGUSTA CHRONICLE, Ga,: As- tonishing in many lines. It may be the beginning of understanding of new and extremely important con- cepts. RICHMOND TIMES-DISPATCH: The significance of this thrilling ac- count may go far beyond the fasci- nating interpretation of world hap- penings in connection with man's existence on this earth. Va,: One of the most significant and fascinating books written since the invention of printing. Anyone who has read it can never feel quite the 'same. PASADENA STAR-NEWS, Russell McCarthy: Immanuel Velikovsky is a rebel against almost all human learning. There is plenty of room in the world of thought for rebellion against some of our hoary hy- potheses.

TRUTH, London, W. J. Brown: Make a note of the name. It will make news for a long while to come. Possibly it will go ringing down the corridors of Time. Or possibly not, for the established orthodoxies are more than orthodoxies. They are in- terests; and the interests have at their command immense powers of suppression. The man is a heretic, of course and I see the Bell, the Book and the Candle advancing. Velikovsky's heresies are enormous. They reach to the stars. . . . And what a case he makes! Already the orthodoxies have marked him down. Already the machines of repression are at work.
